repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records of the Michigan Library Association were first transferred to the Bentley Library in 1941, with several accessions thereafter (Donor no. 1514)

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for use without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Michigan Library Association records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

processinfo.p: The pre-1990 accessions of records created by the Michigan Library Association are not fully processed.

bioghist.p: The Michigan Library Association (MLA) was founded in Detroit on September 1, 1891, for the purpose of promoting the cause of librarianship throughout the state. Today the Michigan Library Association's membership includes librarians, library trustees, and library friends groups. For each year since 1891, members of the Michigan Library Association have gathered at their annual conference to discuss and debate topics of concern to Michigan librarians. To further inform their members, the MLA publishes a quarterly journal, The Michigan Librarian.

MLA is closely related to the American Library Association and supports its interest in libraries and library professionals. In addition, MLA cooperates with regional library and state professional organizations, such as the Midwest Federation of Library Services, the Michigan Association for Media in Education, the Adult Education Association, and the State Library of Michigan.

Other activities of the MLA derive from the various sections that make up the organization. The association is composed of seven districts that meet annually to discuss regional issues. The MLA is divided into sections which are called divisions, caucuses, and committees. Divisions are composed of members who wish to promote library service and librarianship within a particular type of library activity. Caucuses are composed of members who wish to promote library service and librarianship and who share the same interest. There are two types of committees within the MLA, operational and activity.

As of 1988, the MLA had 5 divisions, 14 caucuses, 8 operational committees, and 3 activity committees. The divisions at that time were: Academic and Research Library, Children's Services, Friends, Trustees, and Public Library. The 14 caucuses were: Bibliographic Instruction, Community Colleges, Cooperatives, Junior Members Roundtable, Library Education, Management and Administrative, Marketing and Public Relations, Media, Preservation, Reference, Rural Libraries, Specialized Services, Technical Services, Young Adults. The operational committees consisted of: Awards and Resolutions, Conference, Conference Program, Constitution and Bylaws, Editorial Board, Headquarters and Finance, Membership and Promotion, and Nominations. The activities committees were: Continuing Education and Professional Standards, Intellectual Freedom, and Public Policy. These groups do not always keep the same title. For example, they may change from committee to caucus or division.

scopecontent.p: The pre-1990 accessions from the Michigan Library Association (MLA) are available in three broad groups of material which overlap one another in terms of office of origin, dates, and subjects. This arrangement reflects the way the material was received from the MLA.
The papers received with the 1990 accession cover the years 1937-1952 and 1961-1989 with the bulk of the material from 1980-1989.

The papers received in 1993 cover the years 1977-1991 and mostly contain records of the Intellectual Freedom Committee. Accession also includes bylaws, minutes of the Management and Administration Forum, policies and procedures, and minutes of the Executive board, 1981-1983.

The first nine feet (boxes 1-9) consist of five feet of correspondence and other papers arranged chronologically (1905-1964), and four feet of unarranged financial reports, scrapbooks, membership lists, and miscellaneous association records.

The second nine feet of material (boxes 10-18) dates from 1915 to 1969, while the third group (boxes 19-36) dates from 1891 to 1982. The organization of these two groups of material follows the organizational structure of the association. Within the organization records are divided by type of material (such as minutes, reports, correspondence, etc.) and then chronologically.

The organizational structure of the MLA contains eleven types of bodies. The Executive Board is made up of elected officers and two members-at-large. Executive Board records consists of minutes and correspondence dealing with association business. Correspondence of the executive secretary and the president is also found with these records.

Divisions are created either by grouping together similar types of libraries or by grouping together individual librarians who perform similar functions. For most divisions, there are minutes, reports, correspondence, and other materials that record the division's activities. The School Library Division is among the more fully documented, including records regarding its annual fall and spring institutes, and special programs.

did.unittitle: Special Committee-Cooperative Library Service to Extension Students
School Libraries Division-School and Children's Library
Committee on Education for Library Work with Children in School and Public Libraries
Joint Committee for the Development of School Libraries
State Executive Board of School Librarians,
Student Library Assistants Association of Michigan
Manuals of Procedure for District Chairman of the Trustee Division

scopecontent.p: Sections, sometimes called roundtables, deal with specific topics of library service, such as adult education, the Cooperative Caucus, or the reference. Minutes, correspondence, and other material makes up the bulk of the section records.

Activities committees deal with issues relevant to all types of libraries and library professionals. For example, the Intellectual Freedom committee offers support to local libraries dealing with censorship issues and the Legislative committee coordinates the lobbying activities of the association.

Operation committees perform the housekeeping chores of the association. The Conference committee files contain programs of and reports regarding the association's annual conference. The Recruitment and Scholarship committee's records reflect a time when there was a severe shortage of trained, library professionals.

did.unittitle: Librarian of the Year Award Committee
Flyers, Pamphlets, and Materials on Careers and Scholarships

scopecontent.p: Districts represent librarians within a particular geographic area. District records document meetings and other activities which brought together librarians from a specific geographic area.
Records regarding related library groups document the MLA's work with other associations and professional organizations, such as the American Library Association and the State Board for Libraries.

did.unittitle: Proposed Plan for Reorganization of Department of Education

scopecontent.p: The Workshop/Project files document specialized activities of the MLA. These activities include projects such as workshops dedicated to developing services for immigrant groups.
MLA administrative material includes manuals of procedures, committee descriptions, and checklists for incoming chairpersons.
Temporary committees were formed to discuss special topics, such as the effect of the state constitutional convention of 1961 on library service.

did.unittitle: Committee on Education for Library Service
Special Committee to Study Library Laws
Special Joint Committee on State Aid Law

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous was the final category created to contain material that did not otherwise fit into the organizational scheme. These remaining files cover topics such as the use of penal fines to fund library programs.

scopecontent.p: The papers received in this accession cover the years 1937-1952 and 1961-1989 with the bulk of the material from 1980-1989. The accession consists of 8 linear feet and is arranged in 3 series.

The first series, General MLA, consists of papers pertaining to the general programs, operations and finances of the MLA as a complete unit. Series two, Sections, is devoted to different sections within the MLA. This series deals with the various divisions, caucuses, and committees that have an interest in one area of librarianship such as children's services or intellectual freedom. The third series, County Libraries, is a late accession of material from 1937-1952 and deals with rural libraries during and immediately following World War II.

The material has been arranged alphabetically by topic. If the topic contained more material than one folder it was divided into subtopics and arranged alphabetically and the chronologically when necessary.

The accession as a whole strongly documents the activities necessary to run such an association. This information can be found in the records dealing with grant proposals, nomination and election of officers, finances, policies and procedures, and planning programs and workshops. These types of material can be found in each series.
Series I: General MLA

This series contains information on the general operations of the MLA. The stronger aspects of this series are the records relating to finances, awards, the executive board, membership, organizational structure, conferences, and workshops. The constitution and bylaws are found within the Policies and Procedures Manual.

This series documents the activities of divisions, caucuses and committees within the MLA. This series has been assigned the general name of sections because the titles of these groups sometimes change. Therefore, the titles of division, caucus, and committee have been omitted. This series also includes organizations not directly a part of the MLA, but which support MLA objectives. Examples of these organizations are the Council of Michigan Library Organizations and the Library of Michigan.

The most strongly documented sections include Children's services, Continuing Education, Educational Foundation, Friends, Intellectual Freedom, Legislative, Michigan Interorganization Council on Continuing Library Education, Public Libraries, and Young Adults. Each of these sections have varying research value.

The largest section is Children's Services consisting of approximately one linear foot. The collection strongly documents Spring Institutes, and Summer Reading Programs. This section contains a fairly complete record of minutes spanning the years 1975-1988 that document the issues of the group and how they were addressed.

did.unittitle: Principles for Planning Children's Services in Public Libraries in Michigan
Share Your Success Publications I and II
Membership Rosters and Officers and Committee Members

scopecontent.p: The Educational Foundation is a section of the MLA was started in 1980 with the purpose of giving librarians the chance to participate in continuing education programs. However, in 1985 the Educational Foundation was dissolved. Their funds were transferred to the MLA. The dissolution is well documented.

did.unittitle: List of Friends of the Library in Michigan

scopecontent.p: The mission of the Friends of the library is to create and maintain an association of persons from outside the librarian community who are interested in libraries and wish to their support. The strongest documentation is found in the section's history, membership lists, minutes, public relations and newsletters.

did.unittitle: Michigan Interorganization Council on Continuing Library Education

scopecontent.p: The Michigan Interorganization Council on Continuing Library Education section encourages and facilitates statewide planning for professional development and the continuing education of library and information service personnel. The material on proposals and grants and the section's correspondence depict their activities.

did.unittitle: YA Program Sourcebook and Basic Paperback List

scopecontent.p: This material on county libraries was received in 1990 from the MLA who obtained it from the Jackson District Library. The memorandum that accompanied the material is located in the first folder. The series is comprised of information concerning the running of county libraries during and immediately following World War II. Of research interest are the materials dealing with activities relating to the war post-war planning. This information is best documented in minutes, correspondence and workshop records.

The mission of the Friends of the library is to create and maintain an association of persons from outside the librarian community who are interested in libraries and wish to their support. The strongest documentation is found in the section's history, membership lists, minutes, public relations and newsletters.
